newsitem.title: BELGIUM: No French request to change fish mesh sizes, Commission says.
newsitem.headline: No French request to change fish mesh sizes, Commission says.

text.p: The French government has so far made no request to the European Commission to review a decision on minimum fish mesh sizes, Fisheries spokesman Filippo di Robilant said on Thursday.
French fishermen have since Tuesday blockaded French Channel ports in protest against EU rules calling for larger holes in the mesh of nets which they say could halve their catches.
But on Thursday the fishermen suspended the blockade while they held talks with French Agriculture Minister Philippe Vasseur.
"The French government must take the initiative," Di Robilant told a news briefing, adding that the Commission was always ready to review decisions.
Under a new regulation due to come into force on January 1, 1998, minimum mesh sizes for fixed nets used for catching sole will be raised to 120 mm from 80 mm.
The regulation, which primarily affects French fishermen, does not cover nets towed by trawlers.
"It's necessary for conservation reasons," Di Robilant said, adding that the French port blockade was "another clear piece of evidence that there are too many fishermen for too few fish."
Di Robilant noted that the regulation was approved by EU fisheries ministers in December 1995 and during the past 16 months no-one had complained.
The first round of early French elections are due to be held on May 25.
